posts.cooked: I have been a lead mentor for team 4311 for 7 years. When I started I knew nothing about robots I was just a physics teacher who was asked to help out. I am a lot more competent having skills in many of the FRC disciplines though precision metal manufacturing is not a realm I have been a part of. I have been asked to come up with a dream list of machines that I would like. I am writing to hopefully for advice on where to start to put together a shop? Currently we have a drill press, a hydraulic band saw, 3d printers and hand tools. Anything we need custom we get help from other FRC teams in the area. It would be very helpful if you listed brands that you have really enjoyed or are very user friendly for those with less experience. Thanks!

posts.name: Ian Bae
posts.cooked: i think the biggest upgrade yall can get is definitely a cnc router. i tend to favor shopbot cncs as they have many options for different uses and theyre not too hard to use and maintain. its also pretty easy to learn how to CAM and use a cnc

link_counts.title: Top CNC Router Manufacturer | ShopBot Tools | Made in USA

posts.name: Max H.
posts.cooked: I agree that a cnc router would be a big upgrade, but also a laser cutter is crucial for my team in rapid prototyping and can be used for many things outside of traditional robotics such as fundraising for the team.

posts.name: Rahul Yarlagadda
posts.cooked:
This Sheet is private

Pinging @AllenGregoryIV for any updates as well.

EDIT: Updated guide here: Need advice on starting a shop - #9 by Emilio
What affordable lasers do you recommend?

posts.name: MrBasse
posts.cooked:
ccrocker:

affordable lasers

These two words don’t really belong together…  That being said, after years of service out of my Epilog laser in my classroom I have just invested the end of my budget on a Xtool p2 and I’m very happy with it so far.  It has a lot more smarts built in than my old machine, but with that comes a lot of “dumbing down” of the use of it.  I liked the old Epilog because kids had to learn how it works to use it, and with the new stuff with cameras and auto height detection, you can throw parts in and cut them and they are almost perfect every time.

The P2 is great so far, it works and has some intelligence built in.  The P2s has a lot more smarts in it, and I opted for the cheaper P2 to force some learning to happen while working the equipment.

posts.name: jgwentworth96
posts.cooked:
There’s a couple local teams near us that have Thunder lasers and like them a lot. I’m not sure how pricing compares to other brands. Think they’re a nicer chinese brand.

https://www.thunderlaserusa.com/laser-engraving-machines/

posts.name: Ian Osborn
posts.cooked:
CNC Router.

You’ll also need something to size raw material for that. So a table saw or circular saw with work bench. (could be a 4x8 sheet of ply on saw horses - but you’ll need something to size down sheet goods to more manageable sizes).

A CNC opens up the next level of robot design with MUCH lighter parts. CNC cut tubes are a game changer as is FAR more accurate polycarbonate parts.

A router allows for far more rapid prototyping of stuff like intakes and game element handling.

It’s basically a step function change in the robot.

A larger dust collector and often a larger air compressor are often required for a CNC.

At the more basic level, a band saw and some sort of pedestal belt or disk sander is very useful. A miter / chop saw (with a metal blade) for sizing tube is also useful.

posts.name: Emilio Parra
posts.cooked: Here is our Updated list. The first 1,000 and first 10,000 haven’t been updated since 2021. The First $2000 and next $6000 are now combined in one place.

posts.name: Mike Corsetto
posts.cooked: Love that Spectrum is keeping up with these lists, an amazing and well thought out resource for the community. Great work.

posts.name: Stewart Riley
posts.cooked: Like many others, I’ll tell you that the most important tool you can buy at this point is a CNC router. Unfortunately, the brand that I (and a lot of other people) would recommend is the Omio X8-2200 (or it’s big brother the MPC-125 if you have the space and the extra cash.) We bought one back in 2021 and haven’t regretted it a day. Very easy to use and good quality machining. I prefaced that with “unfortunate” because the Omio is made in China and is now subject to (at latest news) 55% tariffs, which makes the $4000 machine we paid for seem like a bargain. Worse, right now they’re hard to get ( WCP lists them as out of stock, but Swyft Robotics will do a pass-through order to get them shipped directly from Omio in China. That means you don’t have to try to deal with the tariffs yourself, but the price is now $5000 (and that was based on the 30% tariff rate, not the new 55% one, so if you actually order it you may find the price is even higher than $5000.)

posts.name: Ardiano Works
posts.cooked:
How big is your building.  our 2 cars garage is enough to do fab, assy, and storage.

A few 120 20A circuits. 240V 20A is nice to run 220 CNC Spindle.

Mini Mill, either Grizzly G0704 or similar.

Mini 10X24 lathe. Mine is Vevor brand, cheap but works.

4X2 or 4X4 CNC Router. I’d go with Shapeoko Pro to start. If budget allows, go with AVID 3X3.

Air compressor (California Air), You’ll need these to run aluminum on CNC plus for other things. You can use other brand, but get the quite one.

Tool boxes, few cordless drill/impact, etc

4X4 work table or island.

posts.name: Dale Yocum
posts.cooked:
It used to be that the first CNC machine I’d recommend is a CNC Router like others have mentioned.  When I was asked to help restart the Santa Catalina school’s C-Otters FRC team 6665, who had no real CAD skills, I started with a 100w Laser cutter instead.  That needs much less skill to operate and, with the addition of SRPP material (like Rev’s Max Composite) not once did we say “wow, I wish we had a CNC Router.”

We have a Omtec 100w Laser , around $4k not on sale.

We used off the shelf gussets for the most part from Rev Robotics.

A CNC router can do everything a laser can do (in an FRC context) and more.  It requires more skill to use well, is more expensive, and consumes more things like spoil boards and bits.  My previous team, 1540, uses their Shopbot constantly.

link_counts.title: Amazon.com: OMTech 100W CO2 Laser Engraver with Water Chiller & LightBurn, 28"x20" Cutting & Engraving Machine with Air Assist, 4-Way Pass, Caster Wheels, RDWorks, for Wood, Glass, Acrylic & More

posts.name: Josh Sirota
posts.cooked: Does anyone have any clue if a 50W CO2 laser will successfully cut SRPP?

posts.name: Dale Yocum
posts.cooked: Many have used 80w laser for SRPP.  You’d have to play around with the passes and speeds to see if you can make 50w work.

posts.name: Wen Pan
posts.cooked: A cheap belt sander or a disc sander would be helpful. It’s hard to cut a piece (an aluminum tube for example) precisely to a length, but with a belt sander, you can first cut the tube a little bit longer (less than 1/8 inch), and then you sand it down till you get it being exactly the length you wanted.
